ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A strong understanding of the verb system in Hebrew including more verb groups and converting between the active and passive forms of verbs. Also, more vocabulary (e.g. prepositions)

I improving my speaking, reading, writing, and listening skills. This was the semester that I feel like I finally reached a level in my language skills where I could learn in Hebrew and understand and speak much better.
Verb conjugating is definitely A big focus of this class. I also learned a lot of new vocabulary

This course did a great job at exposing students to a variety of skills. There was a good balance of reading, speaking, listening, and writing activities. There was a large focus on different verb tenses and conjugations, as well as knowing when to use which conjugations when given a sentence with a blank for the verb.
Learned how to confidently speak in the past, present and future tenses for all types of verbs. Additionally, increased proficiency when speaking Hebrew.
My Hebrew improved a lot. I gained a lot of vocabulary.

The L4 class helped solidify my understanding of previous concepts in Hebrew (vocabulary and grammar especially) while simultaneously expanding my knowledge base of the language through the introduction of topical vocabulary (eg that of climate change), an in-depth introduction to past tense conjugation, and a fascinating foray into Israeli culture through various media

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course is taught very well. We had plenty of time to learn the material in each unit and it was presented in an organized way. I wished that we had more cumulative practice assignments.
Strengths: variation of class activities, different subjects, mix of projects and grammar work, and class community.

The biggest strength of this course was that it was extremely organized and clear. I also loved the small class environment and small class discussions. The biggest weakness was that there were simply too many verbs and vocabulary to learn, so in the end, I wasnt really able to learn it all.

I truly don't have any complaints about this course. As a language requirement, it is always tough meeting everyday. However, this course was very manageable while gaining a lot of knowledge along the way.
This class was a nice and chill way to improve my language skills.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to anyone who is interested in learning Hebrew, especially if they want to develop a better syntactic understanding of the language.
Yes! If they want to learn hebrew, this is a great way. Its fun and you learn a lot.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. If you are interesting in improving your skill set in Hebrew, while having a very manageable work load, this is the course for you. The content is challenging, but the Professor is great in answering every question along the way and making sure you understand everything being taught.
Absolutely! Orit is a great teacher and the workload is not too much. This class is a great way to continue to hone your Hebrew skills.
Yes. If someone wants to continue developing their Hebrew I would definitely recommend the class.

Yes, especially for practical concerns. For those who took L3 and are contemplating continuing their studies in Hebrew, Id definitely encourage them to proceed with L4, both because of the richness of the language itself but also because of the great quality of the Hebrew teaching department at Yale. Also, Professor Orit was especially engaging and fun, and that was definitely a perk of this course.
